DOC.HEAD: West and East Berliners Celebrate Christmas Together
DOC.TEXT: Leonard Bernstein transformed a Christmas performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony into an appeal for brotherhood as West and East Berliners mingled freely in the divided city for the first Christmas in 28 years. ``I am experiencing a historical moment _ incomparable with others in my long, long life,'' the American conductor said during the nationally televised performance Monday. Bernstein conducted an international group of musicians in the Schauspielhaus, capping three days of performances that celebrated the demise of the Berlin Wall and the struggle for freedom throughout Eastern Europe. The Ninth Symphony was inspired by German writer Friedrich Schiller's 18th century poem ``Ode to Joy.'' In the concert, Bernstein substituted the word ``freedom'' for ``joy'' in the chorus to reflect his personal message. The 71-year-old musician conducted the same symphony at the Philharmonic in West Berlin in a performance timed to end at midnight Saturday, when West Germans were allowed to travel without visas into East Germany for the first time. More than 1,000 people poured into the Schauspielhaus for the 10:30 a.m. Christmas concert, while hundreds more packed the square in front of the concert hall to watch the performance on a giant television monitor. The concert was also broadcast live in more than 20 countries by satellite. Bernstein united an international group of musicians from East and West Germany as well as the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ the four victorious World War II allies still technically responsible for governing Berlin. The East German government presented Bernstein the ``Star of People's Friendship.'' In the city, hundreds of thousands of Berliners passed freely through the wall via crossings created in the concrete barrier after East Germany threw open its borders six weeks ago. West Berliners had to wait up to three hours to cross into East Berlin by car and there were long lines at two new crossings at the Brandenburg Gate. One West Berliner riding a bicycle and dressed up as Santa Claus failed to persuade border guards to let him through ahead of the rest of the crowd. Berliners packed cafes and restaurants on Unter den Linden, East Berlin's most elegant boulevard, while in West Berlin, street vendors did a brisk business selling sausages on a cold, sunny day. East German border police reported that 274,500 East Germans had crossed into West Germany, while 268,000 West Germans went into East Germany. It was busier in Berlin, however, where 220,000 East Berliners went West and 257,000 West Berliners went East.
